message: for example, i have a form with one drop down that has two selections in it. if a user selects first option, two additional text input fields appear. if the user selects second option a check field appears instead. or something along those line, you get the idea.
and then option parameter is used to build additional fields...
is this still valid?: https://code.djangoproject.com/wiki/CookBookNewFormsDynamicFields

i suppose.. so 1st step: /form/ loads empty form with just a dropdown field. 2nd step: user selects an option from the drop down, this in turn triggers onChange() JS, which reloads form with smth like /form/?option=1
would that be a common approach to this problem?
JS is the best solution to this problem. At least from a pure usability standpoint.
If you catch a form at the right time, you can insert and delete fields all you want. (In Django)
And if you don't need to do it in real time, using JS, this is the article you should read http://jacobian.org/writing/dynamic-form-generation/ by @jacobian

@rytis Just output the whole form with all possible fields, but have style="display: none;" set on the hidden ones. Then put an onchange function on your drop-down that checks the selected value and unhides the relevant field (and hides the other one in case it switches). Something like:

Oh, and on the server side, be sure to ignore the appropriate field based on which item was selected, as well (because even though it's hidden, the user might have selected one, filled in some of the info, then selected the other, thereby leaving data in those hidden fields).

Yes, that's what I was talking about. Us JS to show and hide fields when appropriately. On the Django side, you can see what was selected in the post, del the fields you don't need, etc., then push the post into the form and validate.
